column8:
Skiing was good but a number of lifts don't open till 10am and are stopped by 2:30pm. Given the limited number of lifts I feel all lifts should run from 8:30am until at least 4pm.
Also, when people have paid for a lift ticket charging another $10 each, adults and kids, to use the toboggan Park is a rip off.  I emailed Selwyn asking about this but never received a reply.
One last point, like every resort their reports should not be believed. The other day there were large patches of grass with no snow but their report stated excellent cover of 40cm base.

column8:
Not very family friendly

I have a wife who has not skied and a 4 and 5 year old who had never seen real snow. We had never skied in Australia before. We wanted to book ski classes for my wife and children and buy lift tickets for all.

The group classes were booked out on the day we could go and the only available class was a private class at 9.30 am. The private classes do not come with lift tickets so we bought day passes.

We left Canberra in high hope at the crack of dawn and stopped in Cooma to hire gear. In the confusion I left my ski boots at the hire shop and I arrived in Selwyn without boots. No problem, I thought, I would hire boots at Selwyn.

On the road still at about 8.30 am we realised we were going to be late, and so we called Selwyn to see whether we could re-schedule the class. The answer was no, there were no other classes available, and we had lost our money. When I went to hire the new boots, the answer was no, they would not fit them to my skis for reasons of company “policy” and I had to hire a complete new set. When I asked whether we could hire a toboggan while waiting they said yes, but we would need special toboggan lift passes and could not use the skiing day passes we had.

When they subsequently discovered there were group classes available at 1 pm, the told us we had to pay again without any credit for the cancelled class and that we needed new lift passes. After an argument we gained a small credit for the lift passes we had.

The ski classes were run between the two buildings and neither child got out on to the snow proper because of the “mix of skills of the children” until I went to take the 5 year old from his class and have a proper ski.

In summary, the snow and the sun were magnificent but the Selwyn Snowfields resort does not own the snow and the sun. At every turn we found a policy that made the experience un-family friendly.

Sure, in the mess of organising skis, gloves, goggles, helmets, stocks, and fitting them to the excited body parts of a 4 and 5 year old, I, somehow left my boots in Cooma, and sure, after naively accepting the class start time of 9.30 am we were late. But we are a family, a fairly normal family wanting to do fairly normal things at a resort that advertises itself as family friendly.

Well, it is not that family friendly when you get into the detail but has a series of unnecessary policies that will view you as a walking wallet, nothing more. The snow is great, but prepare yourself mentally for everything else.

column8:
A great experience.  Similar to smaller operations in North America. Many repeat customers.  Be early if it is going to be busy.  Well organised parking. Telstra coverage only ? (But not a lot of Telstra customers.)  Well run and orderly.  ATM and eftpos on site, but take cash for contingency, as well as nibblies as queues can be very long at odd times. Plan to leave from 4pm.
Do not take Boboyan road unless you are in a high clearance 4WD. Google is your friend. Google maps can still shaft you. Generally less chance of snow than the other two, but a really good option.  Book early. arrive early and have no expectation of ersatz European architecture. Will do again.

column8: The staff are very friendly and helpful, the instructors are wonderful - very patient with kids, it's very family friendly (it's not too large and not huge numbers of people) and far more economical then the other bigger resorts. The views are beautiful there as well. You can bring your own food if you want to and all the equipment available for hire was more than adequate. As it was both mine and my kids very first time seeing snow (and skiing), it was a very positive experience and I highly recommend it!

column8:
Took my kids there recently for their first visit to the snow  and was a bit disappointed .

The facilities are old and in urgent need of renovation to bring them up to todays standard.

They tried to charge admission to the Toboggan slope so that I could take some photo's of my kids, even though I had no intent ion of getting on a toboggan.

The price of food is unbelievable, so take your own, and the attitude of the staff in the Cafe is pretty ordinary. While my kids were making up their mind of what they wanted from the very limited selection the girl behind the counter responded " That's alright I'm here until  4". When she told my kids that there would be a wait on their "Cheeseburgers"  they responded "That's OK we're here all day"

For a minimal investment it wouldn't be hard to put a couple of benches around the Toboggan slope

The kids enjoyed themselves

column8:
Amazingly frustrating process to get tickets, considering we pre-booked for a group of 6 for 3 consecutive days. Not really anyone's fault, as ticket printer was offline and someone had to go look for some (albeit after waiting for some 20-30mins for the check-in person to find and deal with our booking and move our morning lessons to the arvo, as the wait in line took us beyond the 9:00am start time for kids).

Once day one teething problems were sorted, everything else was good. The instructors were good, the food was decent for a place like this, and most things went by with minimal fuss.

But as someone has already mentioned in other reviews, the toilets do need attention.

column8: The snow was great for learning to ski. The weather 2 out of 3 days was beautiful. It is also very relaxed. However, it is understaffed. And about half the staff that were there were rude, apathetic or disengaged or a combination. Consequently the service is very slow and chaotic. One staff member  doesn't know what the other is doing. I had an impression of ski instructors being conceited and they lived up to those expectations although we learned quite a lot from them in a short time. It's worth going especially with learners and kids but allow 90 mins more than you think to get hire gear organised and fitted, even when pre booked.

column8:
05/08/2017' Almost blizzard​! I went alone with high hope and hired skis with two day pass. Skis were not waxed well... Dropped my two-day lift pass in a black diamond run on the first day due to my skill and weather +/- skis. I went to the info staff and told her I dropped my paper pass. Staff replied first with "Would you like buy again?" Or I was told to use slope for free but to WALK up the slope with my skis! I asked what to do second day. She replied come back and sit until somebody returns your pass in the morning, which sometimes happens. She offered me if I wanted to buy again. I asked why they could issue the pass again even with my receipt, "Somebody out there is using your pass." Shameful service...
Giving paper pass with a plastic zip tie is not enough in this world. Old ski jackets used to have clear plastic pocket around left sleeve for the pass. But I haven't seen those ski jackets for years. They never warned me not to lose it. They only emphasized to hang the pass out on the jacket somewhere. I complained to the manager. No help. I was told it was the same in all Australian ski resorts. I showed him Falls Creek plastic card. I am sure he knew he was not telling the truth as one of the business operator. Second day's ski rental also gone! I did not go back second day as It was two hours driving from home.
They claim so-called small business like themselves cannot afford chipped plastic card like the rest of the world. Well, it all depends.
A few more issues and I will help them correct all for the public.
Good family area in some aspects. I told a few fellow families not to take kids as this facility is understaffed and dangerous.

column8: Upon arrival, we had to find staff to come to the desk to get tickets to use the lifts. We asked where do we go, response - go over there. And do you have any maps? Nope, when you go over there, just take a photo of the one that's on the board. Oh ok, great. So unhelpful. We were advised all lifts would be operational, only 2 were till 1230pm then 1 more opened. We also asked a lift operator if there was a bar to get a drink with lunch, response - yep, in the canteen head up stairs, bar is up there. Excellent. We go to the canteen, stairs are closed off... Staff advised that the bar has been closed for the past month on Monday through Thursday. As we went around the park we saw 2 different instructors being rude to the people getting lessons. One was yelling a a child for falling over as he was holding up the rest of the group and is not to fall over anymore!!! None of the staff appeared interested in being there. We are fortunate enough to work in a ski hire shop, and will not be recommending this park to people. For the price paid and the experience offered, it is worth paying the extra to head to one of the other resorts. I suppose 'you get what you pay for', but this experience was much less.

column8:
Do not lose your lift pass. If you lose it, they refuse a  replacement. I lost mine on my first day of two day pass and gear hire, I had to go home after 3 hours of skiing on the first day.
Having not been given this info at the time of purchase, I went to info desk to ask for replacement. The staff's first comment was "would you like to buy another?". Or "You have free to use the slope but have walk up the hill afterwards." Not nice.
No skiing on second day either.
Family not friendly and safe. Understaffed and I was two kids falling and hitting their heads to lift chair in those 3 hours. They cannot afford to help kids because of understaffing. Without helmets, they would need onsite ED.
A cheap place to go but there is a good reason.
column11:
Do not lose your lift pass. If you lose it, they refuse a  replacement. I lost mine on my first day of two day pass and gear hire, I had to go home after 3 hours of skiing on the first day.
Having not been given this info at the time of purchase, I went to info desk to ask for replacement. The staff's first comment was "would you like to buy another?". Or "You have free to use the slope but have walk up the hill afterwards." Not nice.
No skiing on second day either.
Family not friendly and safe. Understaffed and I was two kids falling and hitting their heads to lift chair in those 3 hours. They cannot afford to help kids because of understaffing. Without helmets, they would need onsite ED.
A cheap place to go but there is a good reason.

column8:
Excellent ski/snowboard destination for beginners/average skiers. Price is also very reasonable as compared to other ski destinations. BBQ area helps family to lunch/eating options. Cafeteria must make more options available to customers (there's hardly anything to fill yourselves up).

Suggestion: Toboggan area must have an escalator to bring people up. As most of the users are kids, they get too tired after 2-3 rides.

column8: Excellent small ski field.  Prices compared with Thredbo Perisher are outstanding.  $45 for day ticket, $45 to rent skis boots and poles.  All Head brand modern and new.  Not a lot of black diamond runs but enough for a great day of skiing.  This resort is ideal for families and newbies and for anyone who just wants to ski for value not surrounded by posers and snow bunnies so familiar at the big name resorts.  Highly recommend!😃

column8: Advertised as a family friendly ski resort, when you arrive the queues for prepaid prebooked tickets do not move, the staff are unfriendly and unhelpful. The only bright spot was that the instructor for the beginners snow boarding was patient and knowledgable. When lunchtime came around the cafe/bistro was not serving normal customers as a school tour group was there and had prebooked their lunch. Stood for 20 minutes while the staff served the tour group and the only response received was that they  were getting smashed and that 4 staff had left. Cafe staff were extremely apathetic to customer queries. When I complained to the cashier his response was that it was not his problem. The management of this so called resort need to either start to provide the resources to do the job properly or get out of the hospitality industry. Will not recommend this business to anyone.

Entrance to the national park is $29. Parking can be a bit challenging on the weekend if you arrive later than 10am. Tubing is awesome! $35 for 10x and the best is you can share among your friends or family. Quite a long q on the weekend but its worthed! Ski and tobogan are also available. Rest area is available. Toilet is unbearable!! The smell.....beyond believe. I guess its just the way its.. no water in the bowl. All staff are really friendly and ready to answer all your questions with a smile 😊

This is perfect for beginners learning to ski and board. Only a few slopes, but that's all you need to learn.
We went July 14th and the chair lift queues were less than 2 minutes.
You can hire your gear there, but get there super early to do that because that takes a really long time, and book it online which saves a little time.
You can park right next to the slopes, about a 100 metre walk.
They have benches and tables at the top of the run which is handy for picnics, and a shop selling nuggets and chips and burgers etc. About $10 for burger and chips from memory.

column8:
Really good terrain for a beginners ski resort and very family friendly. If you are a solid green run skier and/or ready to start skiing blue runs then you will love Selwyn. However, if you like a real challenge or long runs then it's best to stay away as you will just be frustrated.
Also, the facilities are quite basic and run down...lift your game Selwyn and invest some money in the place. Try and add a couple more long runs while you are at it and replace the Racecourse T-bar with a reliable chair lift or add a lift from the bottom of Racecourse to the top of Powerline.

column8:
Great place for young kids who just want to snow play. Entry price to the tobogganing area includes a toboggan. Cash gets you on the rides quicker. Parking is close to the fields. Kids loved the tube as well.

4 stars only because food options are limited. Best to bring your own food, the cafe is over priced and the quality of food is terrible (self service is not hygienic).

column8: Good place to visit. But staffs are poorly trained to help customers. And too expensive to hire boots and suits.
column11: Good place to visit. But staffs are poorly trained to help customers. And too expensive to hire boots and suits.

column8:
Zero service management. Although, It is good for beginners who wants to do skiing, they must provide some good customer service for visitors.
In their website there is no option to opt only for ski training without lift pass. They charge $100 for a lift pass, but the same can be bought for $50 with GroupON coupon. So we wanted to buy only ski training from there website. We called them dozen times to enquire about training pass, snow fall etc. But no one picks up the call.
If you have an option to rent ski costumes, somewhere where you are staying, then it is always better to get them there, instead of standing in long queues in selwyn. Yes, very very long queues ( nearly an hour) even if you want to rent a single helmet as well. If they are ready to accomodate hundreds of people in their resort, they should also think of having multiple customer service points, multiple costumes rental services. It is totally waste of time to wait in so much long queues first for paying, and then for checking your size costumes, exchange rooms, etc. Trust me, you will feel frustrated by their services, if you go on weekends peak seasons.
Second thing is no mobile network, no internet, no wifi. They should have atleast provided wifi just like in Perisher. It is really difficult to communicate with family members without mobile in a strange place.
Third thing, the most horrible toilets. Kids were crying and refusing to go inside the toilets, because of very bad and pathetic smell. Worst part is, there is only one toilet place in the entire Selwyn. They charge us so much for entry fees ($40 per day), trainings, lift, tubbogan etc. Why can't they maintain clean toilets.
Fourth and last thing is, there is no good restaurant or food court which provides food for whole day. There is only one food canteen, which close there meals section once all the burgers( they already preapred for a day) are over. We went to have meals at 12.30 on Sunday, but there was nothing available except french fries. Its always good to carry your own food.
Apart from all the above, I liked the ski training for beginners. If you have kids, they will definitely enjoy tubbogan and ofcourse snow.

column8: We had a lovely day out on the slopes, the lifts ran smoothly but the rest of the resort was definitely understaffed (which you're probably already aware of). The staff were trying their best and eager to please but it took well over an hour to pay for tickets etc. and get through equipment hire. Also a lovely lady in the food service area was visibly sick and I overheard her say that she still had to work due to the lack of staff. Not only is this a health risk to others, but herself also. However, I still had a fabulous day, the crew were friendly and hopefully you work to develop it into a bigger and more efficient resort :)

column8:
First time to the snow for our family of 4
We went in mid September cause and Snow was more than enough for first timers and we virtually had the place to ourselves with maybe 100 people there
Great place to learn with a easy beginner run
We would recommend bringing your own food and snacks which we and most others did basic food and drinks available but as you can imagine expensive
Plenty of families nice easy going atmosphere
If your a first timer definitely consider Selwyn in Spring
We hired our gear from Go Play Outside at Talbingo and had a great experience with very competitive pricing
Go Play Outside is on the way to Selwyn and makes for a casual easy going fit out without the craziness of the resort hire shop
We also stayed at Talbingo which is 40 mins from the Resort cute little town with all you need for a ski holiday if a house style accommodation is your thing

column8: Even during the school holidays the slopes weren't too crowded - although the kiosk was overflowing and the place STUNK from the indoor pit toilets. column8: Pretty small (however I’m used to Perisher) bathrooms reeked, very crowded inside with very limited option in terms of food. Some of the mountain is inaccessible for snowboarders due to the poma. However, good place to learn, snow was good. Most of the staff seemed friendly however one of the staff kept urging me to go up the tbar with a partner so I just didn’t go back. Would recommend to families just starting out.

column8:
Great ski resort for families of primary aged kids.  Short runs make it good for beginners.  Lift staff are really friendly and helpful; they assist kids who might have trouble. Lots of snow machines to increase cover.  Longer runs are normally in the trees which can be interesting for more experienced skiers.

Picnic tables at the resort make it possible for non-skiers to hangout or to -at least partially - self cater. Great for a short (1 or 2 days) skiing with primary ages kids.

column8:
Avoid this place. No good.
We went there last year (2018).
We was attracted by their website claiming it is a family friendly ski resort. After going to Perisher for 3 years we decided to try somewhere different. So we went to Selwyn Snow Resort for 4 days.
One afternoon, when using the chair life, my son (7 years old and can ski freely on green trails) sat too fast when the chair came, he fall down under the chair, was dragged at least 5 meters! Luckily I was with him at the time however I was on the chair already and couldn't jump off to rescue. The life operator didn't stop the lift immediately, instead he ran up and tried to drag my son out from under the chair! I cried out and ask him to stop the lift immediate. My son was so scared and didn't stop crying. The back of his ski jacket had a long cut by the sharp metal under the chair and his back was injured too, with broken skin and a few drops of blood. If the guy stopped the lift immediately (he stood less than a meter from the control button) all the injury can be avoid. How much loss they will suffer from stopping the lift once?!
Because of the pain and scare, my son couldn't walk fast. The operator became very impatient and kept yelling us to move out quickly and don't block other people's way. Didn't even ask or offer a checkup. A rescue snow motorbike passed and stopped to ask if everything was ok, however the rider refused to take my son up to the Centre despite he did drive up to that direction. My son was too scary to take the chair lift again, so we had to walk up the hill by ourselves holding ski boards on hands! On deep snow! My son's shoes were all wet when we walked up the hill.
The the second day, we went to the information desk and made a formal complaint. The lady was nice but didn't show much interest in investigating. Wrote down our contact detail but we heard nothing from them ever since.
We won't even go back again, and I am spreading the words among my friends and business network to avoid this place, just don't want other people to suffer if same thing happens to them.

column8: Don't know if it's always like this but place was chaos today. At least an hour que to pay for hire, another que to collect hire. Then had to buy gloves, they didn't have enough staff to open the shop so kids were stuck without gloves. Food is just basic snack shop stuff, at least another 30-45min que, no trays so I had to balance everything or que twice. EFTPOS wasn't working properly. Just painful. I'll make sure to bring all my own food and gear in future.

column8: We waited over an hour in line just to get to first lot of registers, where only 1 of 3 were open, then another 45 mins to get our hire gear. The toilets are disgusting, the smell absolutely terrible. Other than that, the fields were good for kids and beginners, but some rubber mats along the sides of the toboggan slope would be helpful to the kids and adults trekking back up the hill. With a little bit of TLC & some flushing toilets, this place could be great.

column8:
Cannot recommend this place, especially if u r planning to do tobogganing with kids.  Only after u pay for the kids and yourself u then realise u r not allowed to ride with your 2 year old.  You are forced to leave your kid slide on his own which on a toboggan it can go pretty fast.  They do have a "professional" trainer who tried to give very detailed instructions on how to ride a toboggan to a 2 year old boy, who couldn't even understand a word the trainer said. column11: Cannot recommend this place, especially if u r planning to do tobogganing with kids.  Only after u pay for the kids and yourself u then realise u r not allowed to ride with your 2 year old.  You are forced to leave your kid slide on his own which on a toboggan it can go pretty fast.  They do have a "professional" trainer who tried to give very detailed instructions on how to ride a toboggan to a 2 year old boy, who couldn't even understand a word the trainer said.  There is a sign saying no doubles but having an adult riding with a 2 year old kid seem to concern them a lot.  The staff seem to have no idea why parent want to ride with a 2 year old.

column8: Once you pay $30 to drive in you then have to pay for everything else. Can't bring your own toboggan and go down the slopes for free, staff will stop you and tell you to pay more money to enter the over-crowded toboggan area. Main area with toilets is a mess and untidy, it's not very clean. Understand paying for lift pass for chairlift, but also for j & t bars is a joke.

column8:
A great place to learn to ski. Just spent 3 days with my 11 and 13 year old with no ski experience. Thanks to our (private) lesson with fantastic Nicole, the kids were skiing by 2pm on the first day.
We had one of our ski poles stolen (probably picked up by accident), and the ski hire onsite went above and beyond to resolve our problem, even though we did not hire from them.
All the staff we friendly and it was obvious that this is a family run snow field. We did have a small issue, however the ski team handled this very well.
We did have an issue with another skier and again the staff (ski patrol) were there to sort it out so everyone could get on with a great experience.
If you are keen to learn to ski, this is the place to go. Most people have low ski skills so perfect. Wide runs and no queues! And I mean no (or extremely short) queues - even during the school holidays whilst we were there.
Don’t travel all the way there for the food, however you park your car so close that you can drop by the car to collect your own food. On the other hand, make sure you also support them. Overall is 1/3 the price of the big resorts.
Stop delaying, like I did for years. Go. Your kids will love it.

column8: Very average ski resort. Limited runs. Most of the lower lifts are T-bar and poma's which as a snowboarder isn't very favorable. Food and drinks are very limited. Well maintained slopes. Nice snowy walking areas. Toboggan area could be better. Make it bigger with some challenging areas.
Food in cafe was ok. Was short staffed so busy in line waiting for food. Food was overpriced but that is to be expected in seasonal resort areas.
Hire was a bit of shambles with 3 coachloads of people. They also ran out of many popular sizes. Time for a restock.
Overall a good 1 day experience.

column8: It cost my partner and I $500 for the day. We missed our lesson at 9:30am due to slow cars and trucks along the road. They refused to refund us the money but said we could join the afternoon class which would have been fine if we weren't beginners and we knew how to snow board. So we tried our best but ended up waiting until 2:30 to properly snowboard. Food is expensive and gross. You have to pay 29 bucks to enter Kosciusko National Park (so don't forget to add that to the budget). Staff were rude. I couldn't even go on the lift for a ride unless I had skiis or a board so that was a waste of money. We were thorougly disappointed. Very money hungry business! Turning something natural into a big profit!

column8: The Powerline Poma was closed on 13 Aug 2019 even though there was plenty of snow and perfect weather.  This meant a large part of the ski area was not accessible.  But the lift pass was still full price!

column8: Amazing Snow, record level last week. Kids enjoyed the toboggon, thia is included in the entry price. There are lots of places with heaps of snow to play even if you don't want to pay for it. Heaps of parking. Best to rent gear- snow boots , waterpreof pants etc from Cooma for better prices and less stress. We had to get chains for the tryes. Ours was a large SUV, but 2WD so needed the chains. As you drive up there will be Snow Chain Bays marked clearly. There are around 3 to 5 roughly as you come close to the top. There are boards that will be put which say " Put chain on or turn 4WD ON". From that point onwards, you can put chains on at any of the bays.

column8:
Selwyn is a great family resort and we have been often. Last week (Fri and Sat) I took the grandchildren for their first skiing experience. What a disappointment.  We had booked lessons for our 4 grandchildren in a group class. We should have booked private lessons.
The classes were too big for one instructor who quickly lost interested and focused on those who had at least some ski experience. The grandchildren were turned off to the point where they didn't ant to participate any more. Their parents ended up teaching them after hours of coaxing them back.
The instructors need to lift their game and become more children friendly you really did ruin their experience.

column8:
We were a group of 8. We had no experience with skiing at all. But by the end of second day pretty much all of were able to go down all the runs. The place isn't as busy and it is really well suited for beginners. Did have a hiccup with the booking as a few of us wanted snowboards and we had placed the booking a few weeks back but still they didn't have any at the time. That was utterly ridiculous and disappointing as in it nulls the point of booking. The same went with the classes. I think the office staff is just disappointing at the same time the trainers and the guys working on the snow are awesome. Hope the way they run the place changes.

Stayed in a nearby town, but the ski village itself is perfect for the kids! The drive in was a little scary at it was heavily snowing but if you went at a reasonable speed it was perfectly fine. A great adventure and first time experience for my son at the snow!

Good food options inside with some great coffee, very busy but fun.

Gear hire was fairly easy and parking was good. Make sure you have a ticket displayed or you will get a fine.

column11: Superb

column8:
Great ski resort for families. Cheap pricing.

With the picnic tables, they encourage bringing your own lunch to keep things cheaper.

Be aware that they don't have the number of ski runs like Perisher & Thredbo, but the resort is ideal for the budget-conscious family with younger kids.

If you have kids in their teens, they will probably do all the runs three times over by lunchtime.

column8:
Sorry to say but I will never visit these skifields again for two reasons. (1) Tube operator was a racist. Saw two people from the Indian subcontinent push in the line, he said nothing...He sees an Australian father letting his son take his spot in the line - i.e. with nil net affect on others in line - then directed the son to the back of the line. When challenged he said "this is Australia we are a fair country" - totally oblivious to the fact he just allowed, or refrained from stopping, the Indian people from pushing in. Pure racism. (2) Even though you pay to get into the national park - unable to toboggan anywhere outside the small area - which you need to pay for to use. Attempt to use any other safe hill outside the marked out area and the resort workers pounce.
Overpriced and racist staff - will be going to other more reputable resort next ski season.

column8:
Headed up for ski lessons booked in with 3 hours travel there (and 3 hours back of travel) with an overnight motel stay aswell. Tried to confirm due to lack of snow prior to our lessons via multiple avenues; contacting via website, email and social media.  Instagram enquiry was viewed the day before our lesson but not replied to.
No phone contact is enabled either which we could not fathom how a business could think this was a acceptable.  Turned up and everything was cancelled.  Upon arrival there was others leaving with kids in their cars, frustrated at also having travelled so far without communication.  The staff were defensive and unhelpful.  No compensation was offered besides some snacks and outlining that we can get a refund or reschedule our lesson; as if it was a form of compensation to not charge us for something we didn’t receive.
column11:
Headed up for ski lessons booked in with 3 hours travel there (and 3 hours back of travel) with an overnight motel stay aswell. Tried to confirm due to lack of snow prior to our lessons via multiple avenues; contacting via website, email and social media.  Instagram enquiry was viewed the day before our lesson but not replied to.
No phone contact is enabled either which we could not fathom how a business could think this was a acceptable.  Turned up and everything was cancelled.  Upon arrival there was others leaving with kids in their cars, frustrated at also having travelled so far without communication.  The staff were defensive and unhelpful.  No compensation was offered besides some snacks and outlining that we can get a refund or reschedule our lesson; as if it was a form of compensation to not charge us for something we didn’t receive.

Decent prices, easy to get to over all had an excellent weekend will be back next year

column8: I must give 5 stars to the resort. It was our first ski trip and we had great fun. The facilities are brand new and the staff is very helpful. My wife didn't feel well after the first day and they happily transferred her lift tickets to my daughter and myself so we can ski one extra day. One of the days I forgot to turn off the headlight and the car battery died in the afternoon. They helped us jump start and saved the day. It's just simply a perfect place for a ski trip. Will definitely come back next year.

column8:
This review is for everyone who has been trying to find up to date info about the newly opened facilities. Here is the info you need:
The resort is easy to get to, the parking is huge and well organised. There are a lot of disabled spots about 20m from the front door, and the rest of the car parks are between 30m and 100m from the door roughly. Near enough to grab something you left behind.
The facilities are mostly L shaped. The first area you enter has all the ski and clothing hire. The lines weren't great, weren't the worst, but if you can, do yourself a favour and hire your gear in Cooma before you arrive. Cheaper and no queue. Note you don't get toboggans from this hire area.
The further side of the L has good toilets which never had a queue during our visit, and had warm water for washing hands. Nice! Also gender neutral and accessible toilets.
There is food and drink for sale, it's very much a canteen style place, imagine the set and offerings up at most large places like a theme park. Check out my photos for a record of the menu and prices. The food isn't great, it's pre made burgers, chips, pies, hot dogs etc. I think sandwiches are the most healthy option. Pretty expensive but also super convenient for a warm bite to eat. Eg burger was $15, hot dog $10.
There's also a bar/ cafe with a coffee machine and a good range of milks.
I wish they had water refill stations but I didn't see any, I did figure out you need to ask the bar/ cafe staff for a bottle of tap water (glass cafe style) if you need more water. The canteen staff won't give you a top up.
There are lots of benches to eat at both inside and out though many many people left their stuff on the tables unattended all day, you might need to make room to eat.
There is one bank of lockers for hire, $10 or $15 per day depending on the size. See photo.
I can't speak to the ski/ snowboarding or lifts, but the tobogganing was great. It's situated past the main facilities building, over to the left looking outwards. You use your card (which you get when you enter) to scan into the area where you can collect a toboggan. They have a long travelator from the bottom of the hill up to the top so you don't have to climb it! So good. The ride down is fun too, though definately less bumpy in the morning.
There's loads of spaces around the slopes you can explore to build a snowman etc.
Final note, I saw there was mentions online of a taboggan fast run, and possibly also an ice skating rink etc. These things aren't there, or certainly weren't there in early July 2023.
Overall, amazing time, very fun, great for kids!
Fingers crossed they will update their website with all this info soon!

column11:
This review is for everyone who has been trying to find up to date info about the newly opened facilities. Here is the info you need:
The resort is easy to get to, the parking is huge and well organised. There are a lot of disabled spots about 20m from the front door, and the rest of the car parks are between 30m and 100m from the door roughly. Near enough to grab something you left behind.
The facilities are mostly L shaped. The first area you enter has all the ski and clothing hire. The lines weren't great, weren't the worst, but if you can, do yourself a favour and hire your gear in Cooma before you arrive. Cheaper and no queue. Note you don't get toboggans from this hire area.
The further side of the L has good toilets which never had a queue during our visit, and had warm water for washing hands. Nice! Also gender neutral and accessible toilets.
There is food and drink for sale, it's very much a canteen style place, imagine the set and offerings up at most large places like a theme park. Check out my photos for a record of the menu and prices. The food isn't great, it's pre made burgers, chips, pies, hot dogs etc. I think sandwiches are the most healthy option. Pretty expensive but also super convenient for a warm bite to eat. Eg burger was $15, hot dog $10.
There's also a bar/ cafe with a coffee machine and a good range of milks.
I wish they had water refill stations but I didn't see any, I did figure out you need to ask the bar/ cafe staff for a bottle of tap water (glass cafe style) if you need more water. The canteen staff won't give you a top up.
There are lots of benches to eat at both inside and out though many many people left their stuff on the tables unattended all day, you might need to make room to eat.
There is one bank of lockers for hire, $10 or $15 per day depending on the size. See photo.
I can't speak to the ski/ snowboarding or lifts, but the tobogganing was great. It's situated past the main facilities building, over to the left looking outwards. You use your card (which you get when you enter) to scan into the area where you can collect a toboggan. They have a long travelator from the bottom of the hill up to the top so you don't have to climb it! So good. The ride down is fun too, though definately less bumpy in the morning.
There's loads of spaces around the slopes you can explore to build a snowman etc.
Final note, I saw there was mentions online of a taboggan fast run, and possibly also an ice skating rink etc. These things aren't there, or certainly weren't there in early July 2023.
Overall, amazing time, very fun, great for kids!
Fingers crossed they will update their website with all this info soon!

Runs are easy for beginners, no service and they are completely cashless so we did run into a bit of trouble trying to pay (our own fault) food is no good, just bring your own. Otherwise would recommend for children and beginners. They run lessons all day as well

It is less crowded than Thredbo and Perisher. Buy a $29 day pass into Kosciuszko National Park. There is plenty of snow if you don’t want to buy the pass for the chair lift. We rented our own snow gear and equipment, so our experience on the snow was quite pleasant.

column8:
The building is nice and I like the attempt to modernise. Staff are always friendly and kind. But I can't help but feel as though management missed an opportunity to really WOW everyone on the long awaited return. You don't often get another chance to make a first impression, and I sadly have to report that the experience overall was poor.

We liked:
- ticket machines for the national park pass, although the touch screen was laggy
- attempts to modernise, such as self service ski pass machines
- nice new buildings, and on-site accommodation
- friendly staff

What we didn't like:
- the process to rent ski's was horrendous. Incredibly, horribly slow. There was no sense of urgency, no hustle. We've all driven 5 hours to be there. On one occasion, we waited 30 minutes just to swap a helmet, and we were second in line. It seemed like they didn't have any work benches, so everything had to be done by staff whilst seated on the ground
- expensive food. 8 bucks for a large soy cappuccino. Granted, they now use proper soy milk
- not enough seating. Hundreds of people forced to sit on the ground inside. Those who got a table selfishly left their stuff on it to stop others from using the space. This may be because there weren't enough lockers, but it's more about people lacking courtesy
- slippery tiles in the bathrooms. In the last facility, there were rubber mats laid down
- most of the snow runs were shut down, even though there was plenty of snow. Only the main front runs were operating and they were wearing out
- the T bar lift in the middle kept breaking down, which put huge pressure on the only other run which was to the top. Lines blew out
- getting passes for the second day was a nightmare. It wasn't clear whether our passes from day one were valid for all days, whether we needed to top them up, or whether new passes needed to be printed. There were no staff there to help, 1 out of 3 machines were down, and the line grew and grew. Finally they started working and we got newly printed lift passes.
- at one point I jumped into the line for the shop and gave up after 10 minutes when the line didn't move and there were 10 people still in front of me

Selwyn is a beautiful place and it is great for beginners. If you purchase during the sale period, it's definitely cheaper than all other places around, and its closer to Sydney and Canberra. If they can get their stuff to really hustle I think that would make the most significant difference to the experience

column8:
Poor terrible communication from staff, management was defensive and unhelpful!

2 weeks ago we had lessons booked in and due to the lack of snow leading up to we tried to contact them in several ways, email, social media, website, phone.

Their phone line just guided us to their website, they read our Instagram messages and still didn’t reply.

After driving 3.5 hours with 2 young kids we turned up and saw several other fustrated families who also didn’t receive any communication.

We then spoke to 3 staff/management who were defensive and hopeless with communication! I do not understand how they can simply not pick up the phone and call the people who are booked in for a lesson to let them know it’s been cancelled. After paying for accommodation and a long drive with 2 young kids we still did not receive any communication what’s so ever about it being closed or our cancelled lessons.

All they offered was a refund, no compensation for cancelled lessons with no communication.

We went back last weekend and it was a mess people everywhere didn’t know what to do, people sitting on the floor as there wasn’t enough seating or lockers.

Food was very expensive, tasteless and greasy, staff were also hopeless in that department it was like they didn’t know what to do.

The snow itself was good for our kids they had fun making snow balls and skiing down the slopes, by the lunch time the slopes became very bumpy and rough rather than smooth.

Overall not a great experience and looking to go to Thredbo or Perisher next time.

Great ski resort for beginner and families with kids. This review is for someone who want to discover a new place for skiing.
New facilities with good food, affordable price. We really enjoy our time playing with snow and skiing here.
However, someone who drive from Selwyn to Canberra should be careful with the shortest road on Google Map to Canberra. The road is underconstruction so the surface was so terrible. Try to search another way to come back to Canberra by getting to Monaro Highway. We nearly got stuck in Boboyan Road, and really heard to get out of this terrible road in dark night. We felt so scared that we might stay whole night in dark and cold. So I truly recommend people who want to go to Selwyn, please come there by Monaro Highway although this road will a bit longer than Boboyan Road.

column8: The experience was overall very fun expect the lessons, me and my family had lessons in the afternoon but we had been abit late since we were at the bottom and waiting to get on the lift, there was a long line once we got on we had made it but we found out that we needed helmets which I didn't know so we had to run to the hire place and get helmets which took a long time and once we got to the lessons place my family and I asked around to find where our lessons were since they all split up and we could not find them the other lesson workers all said that they were unsure so we went around but still couldn't find them so in the end we had wasted the money on the lessons we didn't even go to. Today we went again we drove for about 2 hours to get there and find out that there was a power outage and we were told to leave again which was a waste of time since we had driven out there, there was no information about it closing and my family had already bought the lifts which is a rip off.

Made a booking early in the morning for tobogganing. Drove 2.5 hours and was turned away at the entrance because the resort was closed. While I understand that emergency closures can happen, I would greatly appreciate being told -- either when I made the booking if the emergency had happened by then, or via phone (they had my number) so that I could turn around or go somewhere else instead of wasting 5 hours + lots of petrol.

While I understand that emergency closures can happen, I would greatly appreciate being told -- either when I made the booking if the emergency had happened by then, or via phone (they had my number) so that I could turn around or go somewhere else instead of wasting 5 hours + lots of petrol.

column8: The actual facilities and snow fields are ok but the service is lacking. #1 the automated ticket kiosks were out of order. When my wife asked a female member of staff how to rectify she was much more interested in adjusting the TVs than sorting our (their) problem. She actually said 'I'm just trying to sort out the TV' and was fiddling with a remote at the same time #2 The food places inside were cashless. #3 We ordered, and paid for, 4 hot drinks at the Cafe. We were served 3 drinks. When we contested that we paid for 4 and only got 3 the young girl chose to argue. Even after producing the receipt there was no apology and the 4th drink was served reluctantly. The drinks were expensive, which is expected, but tasty enough. There just seemed to be a real lack of warmth or personability to any internal staff interactions inside the main building. Even buying the food there was no 'Hi how are you, have a good day, thank you...........' The food was also ok. The staff at the toboggan Park were nice enough.

column8: Terrible customer service. When I called them to send me the confirmation, I simply said they hadn't gotten back to my email, and Aby, the manager, told me, "Just so you know, Im the only one doing everything here." As if that's my problem. Go tell that to your boss! They have not given the confirmation for the lesson I booked in April. On 5 June, they emailed that the snow was not enough, so I have to choose to refund or credit. I asked them to credit it so i can rebook it myself. It's 11 July as of writting this, and the credit is still not processed. This was supposed to be a birthday surprise for my child, but it was all ruined by their incapabilitirles. No Star for them and to the manager, Aby S. April til July of inconvinience from you guys is unacceptable.

column8: The resort ski facilities are nice. Small pistes. Good for kids. column8: Awesome place to take the family to ski and board. Really family friendly and a great place for the kids to learn. Excellent customer service and friendly staff.

column8:
We recently went to Mt Selwyn. It was the first time my children were seeing the snow, so they were very excited.
It took a very long time to hire a gear and I was getting anxious as it was nearing my children's lesson time. When I reached out to one of the staff they happily changed the lesson time and helped us with our gear, staff were super friendly!

Next it was my (adult) first time ski lesson. Wow, the instructor was so bad, he talked for 1hr and 15mins for 1.5hr lesson. Talked about how dangerous skiing, a huge turn off to first-time skiiers! Everyone in my lesson group were so unhappy and disgruntled. I honestly had a bad experience and couldn't hold it anymore and went to the lesson counter and gave them the feedback. They were so apologetic and thanked me for the feedback. They booked me to another lesson for that afternoon where the instructor (Stefan) was absolutely FANTASTIC! He was so good at teaching and I learnt to appreciate skiing. It's a pity that other people in my first lesson didn't speak up and never got the redemption.

My children's instructors were also fantastic and they enjoyed every minute.

Overall, my family had a lovely time (despite the little bump with my lesson) and would go back again, next year.

column8: Not enough chairs to sit on and no one was taking care of it.
column11: Not enough chairs to sit on and no one was taking care of it.

column8:
Selwyn was a great place for my partner to learn to ski. However, unfortunately there were a few things we weren’t satisfied with.
We emailed Selwyn prior to our trip as we had a question about our ticket. Unfortunately they never got back to us which resulted in us losing quite a bit of money.
Secondly, they did a great job upgrading their new facilities but unfortunately there were things which were not thought about. There was no where to refill water bottles which all other ski resorts offer.
Unfortunately there were MANY inconsiderate families who dumped their belongings on the tables and chairs so one could sit there. They were rude when we asked if we could sit down at their empty table and they said no but then no one even sat there while we sat on the floor. Selwyn should think about putting up signs/offering other alternatives so people don’t have to sit on the wet floor to eat lunch.
It would be good to see Selwyn take on some feedback to make their resort more facilitating to their customers

column8: We were really disappointed in Selwyn snow resort we holiday to the snow fields each year and was excited to go to selwyn after it has reopened but we were disappointed from the get go once we arrived we had heard that selwyn had the best toboggan park but it was far from that Perishers toboggan area is much more impressive then on top of that it only got worse the attitude of the staff was extremely rude and accused us of stealing the Toboggans when we were just heading up to the top of the toboggan park to leave them there then once we got inside to buy some food there was hardly any tables so we ended up sitting on a tiny bit of carpet we spent a total of 2hrs at selwyn was not worth the time or money  to go there we were really disappointed in the place

column8:
We were very disappointed and feeling trapped in this experience. We seeking to have a lesson for first time skier ( for 3 adults and 2 kids). When we paid for it, the staff only say that we need to hire the equipment the next day and all good to go ( he said that in front of my friends and 2 kids). The next day after we are all there, hired all equipment and ready for the lesson, they told us that it is compulsory to have a a lift pass to have the lesson. Which cost as much as lesson+equipment, i explained to him that we just first time skier and we may not need the lift since we don’t know we would like it or not to be ski the whole day. They not agreed, then i said, if that, I wanna refund for lesson because I didn’t know there is the lifting pass cost compulsory involved and they deny it. We finally find the staff we deal with the day before and he lied in front us again about he did explain that there is lift involved in the cost and it it is compulsory. This is the most disappointed part of the day.

We literally trapped in the hole that we have no other choice. We finally still just paid for the lift and attend the lesson as we drove 6 hours to be here already and didn’t wanna ruin our holiday for this ridiculous experience.

At the end of the day, the kids tell us that they didn’t use the lift even once, their instructors told them that they are just first learner so they dont need to, they need to attend another beginner class to learn how to sit on the lift.
This just make the experience more ridiculous.

For everyone that plan to come here for a lesson, please be aware of this so you are not trapped in like we did.

column11: Terrible place indeed. Staff seemed to not care about anyone and only seemed to care about money

column8:
DO NOT BOOK ANYTHING ONLINE… until you arrive and see what condition the snow is in. This will save you stress, frustration, loss of money and an argument with management that is incapable of using common sense and has zero empathy.

** My review wouldn't have been so blunt if management listened to their customers. Even the reply below from Selwyn is heartless and empty. Sorry, but not sorry enough to fix the wrong they have done. They are happy to take money from. people and keep it. If they were genuinely apologetic, a credit or refund would be offered to those who booked online in advance but didn't receive what was offered in the descriptions and images. They did not change the toboggan description. Even today it still says "150 metre snow carpet for effortless laps of fun" . That's a lie. You had to walk back up the new hill. Again, if free or discounted I wouldn't have complained and accepted the declining snow and effort made by Selwyn. But every person paid full price for a below par product. And most we complaining amungst ourselves. I could hear the poor staff copping the verbal abuse. Just wrong on all levels. I hope you are listening Blyton Group or else no one will be back next year. **

On the day you arrive check if the snow cover has deteriorated to either patches of dirt, mud, slush. Check how many Ski lifts are running. Check the Toboggan slope isn't full on dangerous holes. If you have pre-booked tickets online before you arrive, beware.The management team treat you with no respect. Simply stating their terms and conditions show “no refund”. Selwyn this is wrong. A manager is there to manage situations. Not to just read policy and walk away. Selwyn is great for beginners when it has snowed, but it is managed extremely bad when there is not enough snow. Selwyn, you should offer a refund or credit when the product you are offering doesn’t match what you have sold.

Everyone, hold off booking lift tickets & toboggan tickets until you arrive on the day and see if there is enough snow to actually ski or toboggan. And to see how many lifts are actually running. There is no rush to purchase lift passes or toboggan tickets. These do not sell out. So there is no benefit to pre-booking online before you arrive.

The toboggan slope was unsafe and not usable with large holes all the way down but management disagreed. When it was moved to another area which had snow cover, is was shorter and the slope was too flat to slide all the way to the end. Also, no magic carpet to take you up the hill. I have no complaints if that was free. But management still thought it was fair to charge full price of $25 to use this area. Honestly, it is was no different to taking candy from a baby. Shame on you Selwyn. Won’t be back. Next year off to Perisher for free tobogganing on a hill you can slide down without using your hands or becoming injured sliding into large holes.

If you would like Selwyn's management to change, please write a review. No one can control the weather. So i do feel for Selwyn, that it hasn't snowed. But this is not an excuse to take advantage of you and me. They only might consider to do better for next year if they hear from everyone who felt ripped off and taken advantage of.

column11:
DO NOT BOOK ANYTHING ONLINE… until you arrive and see what condition the snow is in. This will save you stress, frustration, loss of money and an argument with management that is incapable of using common sense and has zero empathy.

** My review wouldn't have been so blunt if management listened to their customers. Even the reply below from Selwyn is heartless and empty. Sorry, but not sorry enough to fix the wrong they have done. They are happy to take money from. people and keep it. If they were genuinely apologetic, a credit or refund would be offered to those who booked online in advance but didn't receive what was offered in the descriptions and images. They did not change the toboggan description. Even today it still says "150 metre snow carpet for effortless laps of fun" . That's a lie. You had to walk back up the new hill. Again, if free or discounted I wouldn't have complained and accepted the declining snow and effort made by Selwyn. But every person paid full price for a below par product. And most we complaining amungst ourselves. I could hear the poor staff copping the verbal abuse. Just wrong on all levels. I hope you are listening Blyton Group or else no one will be back next year. **

column8:
Unfortunately, there was very little snow on day 1 of our 3 day ski holiday. We paid a little over $1000 for lift tickets for our family of 4 in March, but spent most of the day walking up the mountain ourselves to ride down the only half decent slope there was. The only lift open was for a short little slope that took about 30 seconds from top to bottom.
I know it’s not the resorts fault that there was no snow and I asked if I could get a credit for next season. The lady was perfectly polite in saying that all she could offer was to have our dates for our lift passes moved to the following week. This, of course is completely impractical as accomodation has been paid for, gear hire has already been paid for, time off work has to be arranged and kids go back to school.
My advice to anyone planning a ski trip here is  to never buy lift passes till they know what conditions are like.

column8:
We plan to warmup at here before going to those more expensive ski fields. However, the return of the 100 dollars ticket is only one lift and one line that even needs to queue. There is still a 1.5-hours drive from Cooma and a parking fee of 29 dollars.

Don’t blame the weather, cause I saw the snow makers stopped before 10 am. Why do I noticed that? Cause I prayed all this morning that even one more line can be opened.

What’s more? When we finally made the decision to leave at noon, buses were coming in. How could they all fit in that little tiny slope? Maybe they can start waiting in line for the lift at the top.

This was my sons first trip to the snow.
We booked ahead (lift tickets and hire gear), but had to wait 40 minutes to be fitted with skis due to a bus of school kids arriving ahead of us.
I would have thought extra staff would be booked mid week to deal with bulk visits.
Instead, we were directed to the back of the line that caters to non prebooked customers. We were not the only ones in this situation.
Not a good experience.
I'm giving Selwyn two stars, only because there was snow.
We'll be going to Thredbo or Perisher next time.

Worst snow conditions I’ve seen. Not their fault, sure, but I was shocked to learn that tobogganing was an extra charge. Definitely should have been included so guests might feel even slightly satisfied after paying so much for the experience.
Checked the snow report the day we were leaving. Completely misleading. Also falsely claiming the triple chairlift was open when it wasn’t. They need to tell people what’s really going on before they buy tickets online and make the journey.

column8:
I have been to Selwyn three times and previously I have had a positive experience. However, this final, third visit has demonstrated that good weather is the only thing that makes this resort worth visiting. So don't book in advance because you don't know what the weather will be like. Or you could just go to somewhere better like Thredbo.

This year the slopes were very patchy and yet the snow machines were not being used in the evenings we were there. Only one lift was operational but other slopes looked good enough to ski down so I – along with many others – climbed the mountain, skied down and then climbed again (something we could have done without paying hundreds of dollars for lift tickets). In response to the terrible weather, the resort offered $25 lift tickets, drawing more people to the single over-crowded lift. The resort offers no refunds for not utilising their snow machines or for keeping their lifts closed. This is in stark contrast with other weather-dependant holiday activities I have experienced where the company offers a free or discounted re-booking. The lack of customer care demonstrates to me that this resort cares more about getting paying customers than giving a positive customer experience.

To be clear, the staff at the resort are lovely (hence the 2 stars). My criticism is of the decision makers of this resort. Those who keep the snow machines and lifts off and those who offer cheap tickets to a single over crowded slope.
column11:
I have been to Selwyn three times and previously I have had a positive experience. However, this final, third visit has demonstrated that good weather is the only thing that makes this resort worth visiting. So don't book in advance because you don't know what the weather will be like. Or you could just go to somewhere better like Thredbo.

This year the slopes were very patchy and yet the snow machines were not being used in the evenings we were there. Only one lift was operational but other slopes looked good enough to ski down so I – along with many others – climbed the mountain, skied down and then climbed again (something we could have done without paying hundreds of dollars for lift tickets). In response to the terrible weather, the resort offered $25 lift tickets, drawing more people to the single over-crowded lift. The resort offers no refunds for not utilising their snow machines or for keeping their lifts closed. This is in stark contrast with other weather-dependant holiday activities I have experienced where the company offers a free or discounted re-booking. The lack of customer care demonstrates to me that this resort cares more about getting paying customers than giving a positive customer experience.

To be clear, the staff at the resort are lovely (hence the 2 stars). My criticism is of the decision makers of this resort. Those who keep the snow machines and lifts off and those who offer cheap tickets to a single over crowded slope.

column8:
We had a blast at Selwyn and Luke M. was amazing!

I took a lesson to improve my snowboarding and Luke M. from Selwyn did a really great job teaching what I am supposed to learn. After the lesson, I felt like my skill was amped to intermediate level with just short amount of time.
Luke is such a cool, knowledgeable, and approachable instructor. He answered all my questions and he even challenged me to do a jump (my first jump) which I successfully executed (didn’t fall!).

I would give 5 stars for Luke M.!

For the resort, I was impressed how convenient everything were. The parking is huge and centre building just easy with all stuff there (rentals, lesson, and cafe). The staff were very friendly and appreciated their response all my newbie questions (like where are the toboggan area, where to snow play, where the lessons meet up etc.)

My kiddo loved the toboggan area. She likes to ride the magic carpet going up to the top for the toboggan. The resort also provide the toboggan so it is not necessary to hire. Note that there is a fee to use it but we think its worth it.

The prices of the food and beverages are reasonable. Its definitely not a like a ‘theme park’ prices like the others.

I just hope that this resort would get a lot of snow soon. We would definitely come back.

The slope of the resort is very beginner friendly and the vibe of other skiers/snowboarders were all good. Its not so intimidating as the other resorts.

column8:
Selwyn Snow Resort is quite good for beginners. We enjoyed the lessons and the skiing. The staff was friendly and helpful. There were only a few trails open in early July. I hope they can open more trails.

My biggest complaint is the communication. The booking website has all sorts of issues. There is only an email enquiry to contact, but it takes weeks to get a response. There used to be a contact number but it's now removed from the website. Dialing the number is just a recorded message without anyone picking it up. I got overcharged with my booking and it still hasn't been resolved after more than a month.

Here are some useful information:

- If you're traveling from/to Canberra, make sure to use B23 the Monaro Highway.

- Similarly, make sure you turn to Link Rd from Snowy Mountains Highway. Google maps may direct you through another trail but that's definitely not for winter.

- The road to the resort is quite good. When we went there it wasn't snowing so snow chain was not necessary. Listen to the local radio for road status.

- There are plenty of parking spaces. It's important to pay for parking, or rather, the national park pass. There are ticket machines on the way to the ski building. You need the license plate number and can buy multiple days of parking at once. We did see ranger checking cars and giving out fines.

- Ski lift ticket can be bought at the front of the building. Or if you booked online, scan the QR code and the ticket will be printed out. You probably don't need to book it prior to arriving but it does make it easier.

- On the other hand, lessons is better to be booking prior to coming as there are limited spots.

- Equipment can be rented once you arrive. It's a slow process as every other reviewer says, so be prepared. The equipment are quite new as the resort only reopened recently.

- There are lockers for rent. $15 for big ones and $10 for small ones daily.

- You can bring your own toboggan and there is a small area where the kids can use it.

column8: We booked lesson and pre-booked hire gear. Arrived on the day 45mins prior to the booked lesson, only to wait in the pre-booking line for well over an hour to get our hire gear, while the walk up line without pre-bookings got served 10x faster. We only had 3 families in front of us in the pre-booked line as well. Staff were incredibly slow to serve and get hire gear fitted. We ended up missing the lesson. Thankfully they did offer to move the lesson to a later time slot which was great. Failed to tell us the kids needed helmets though for their lesson, so had to go back to the diabolical situation of waiting in line all over again for their helmets - this should be something you are informed of when booking the lesson or picking up the hire gear. I can’t fault the ski instructor though, she was amazing with the kids. The resort itself has great facilities, it’s just a shame the hiring of equipment was such a disaster. I would definitely recommend hiring your gear in Cooma on your way through if possible.

column8: Do not go.. do not pre book.. we lost hundred of dollars in pre-booked lift and lesson tickets after they couldn’t open in the middle of the season due to no snow..
column11: Do not go.. do not pre book.. we lost hundred of dollars in pre-booked lift and lesson tickets after they couldn’t open in the middle of the season due to no snow..

column8:
Go to the actual ski fields. It will work out far cheaper.

We drove up one weekend and was closed because too much snow disrupted electricity. The following weekend was barely any snow but we went anyway.

Treatment of staff was ridiculous. We spent well over an hour just figure out where to go etc, as zero signals. Then finally we just walk on and new staff advised we need to purchase several lift tickets to walk in basically. So we complied. Later, the experienced staff tell us that not the case and to get refund for unused tickets.

Have been waiting for weeks now and no refund or response from management. It's not hard to process a refund, nor is it hard to ensure that your staff are trained before you put them in the field.

My son had a great day tobogganing and the snow board lesson was great. I'd just like to get all the lift passes that we didn't need but we're manipulates to buy retuned in full.

I love this ski resort because it suitable to bring kids. New facilities are more comfortable and suit us. A lot of parking lots available, new cafe, new toilet, short distance from parking to the ski entrance. I love magic carpet that is useful for toboggan play. So convenient. Pay $25 to play toboggan and u get 1 toboggan to use here.  No outside toboggan allowed

I hope Selwyn Snow Resort could provide more table at outside. I could see there are a lot more space outside. It’s good to have more table. It’s really convenient

column11:
This ski resort has been upgraded (2023) after big damage from a bushfire (2019).

I love this ski resort because it suitable to bring kids. New facilities are more comfortable and suit us. A lot of parking lots available, new cafe, new toilet, short distance from parking to the ski entrance. I love magic carpet that is useful for toboggan play. So convenient. Pay $25 to play toboggan and u get 1 toboggan to use here.  No outside toboggan allowed

I hope Selwyn Snow Resort could provide more table at outside. I could see there are a lot more space outside. It’s good to have more table. It’s really convenient

column8:
Shameless business. They refuse to refund the presale tickets (I.e. want to keep the proceed from presale tickets without providing services) when they fail to make enough snow like the other resorts do

And I agree with the other reviews. The so call toboggan area was very unsafe. There were holes and bumps everywhere. The slope was so icy. If you fell you would get deep scratches

So irresponsible and unethical

column11: I reckon Thredbo still better for skiing and snow boarding. Selwyn is smaller and entrance fee is bit expensive than Threbo.

column8: There wasn’t a lot of snow fall when we were there in July which is fine, but the machines also weren’t on to help so the whole field was sludge. You couldn’t ride the toboggans as it was so hard and chewed up you couldn’t keep momentum. Paid for the lifts for my son and I and they wouldn’t allow me to ride if I didn’t gear up, which meant my 9yo wouldn’t go on the lifts by himself as he’d never used them before, which was a waste. I contacted customer services and they agreed to refund me my lift pass, which I was grateful for. Months later and back and forth emails they reneged on that and questioned everything I’d relayed in email form after the face to face. So I basically threw away 2 lift passes and 2 tobogganing passes money wise. Will not return. The girl who spoke to customer services for me, was lovely… but overall extremely poor customer service to say the least. (2 stars is generous)

Great place for the beginners and kids. Trails aren easy. Rentals, lessons and chairlifts's price are resonable. Facilities are all new after rebuilding.
It's good idea to keep an eye on the snow cams before coming because the weather and snow forecast are something that unfortunate and shouldn't complain to the resort. So best to make good plan since everything cost lots.
We've been here twice both before the fire and after and will re-visit again next year.
If possible could we get more table for indoor picnic area in the future?
Keep going Selwyn, we have been watching you though the cams that you are working very hard to create best snow experience for everyone. Cheers!!!

column11: Dont pre pay for passes. Their non refund policy is no snow, no refund. Pay for passess day before.  Good little small snow resort for families. Not alot of natural snow fall but work hard to make sure that man made snow was available. Tobogganing is fun.

column8: so I bought two tickets on line as a special deal where you need to pre book dates you intend to ski, I booked my first ticket to go last friday and of course I drove all the way down to find no snow and of course no refund which really sucks , surely the same way you book a flight but then if the flight is cancelled due to poor weather (which happens) your flight is just rescheduled....the way this resort is run compared to before the fires leaves a lot to be desired....very disappointed !!

column8:
We had a great time at Selwyn Snow Resort. We only went for the purpose of toboganning as we are not experienced in snow sports. The tobogan area is large and well equipped. It also looked a good place to learn how to ski or snowboard.

The building is well heated and has a cafe.

A good spot for beginners.
column11:
We had a great time at Selwyn Snow Resort. We only went for the purpose of toboganning as we are not experienced in snow sports. The tobogan area is large and well equipped. It also looked a good place to learn how to ski or snowboard.

The building is well heated and has a cafe.

A good spot for beginners.

column8:
Great resort for families.
Good way to introduce kids to the snow. If you want to keep it simple and cheap you can bring your own food and play with the snow without having to pay for anything. Something that can't be said with other resorts. There are plenty of tables to sit on indoor and out.
You also have an official toboggan and snow tube area. Need to pay $15/$10 per person but the area let's you play all day if you have the energy and toboggans are included in the price.
Snow tubing is $35 per 10 turns but is not limited to one person.
Lifts, ski hire and lessons can be individually purchased or bundled. Prices vary according to the combo you choose.
To get in you need to purchase a national park entrance fee and hire snow chains (even if you don't use them). At the time we went the park entrance was $29 which you pay at the resort as a parking fee. Snow chain hire was $26 which you can pretty much get at any place in Cooma.
Depending how busy it is you need to only park 10 to 200 metres from MAIN building and ski hire right at the entrance.
Food is average pricey fried takeaway food so if you want anything else it is recommended to bring your own. They seem to only accept credit/debit cards
The place seems to be newly renovated and amenities are clean and modern.
On our latest  visit it rain most of the day. 3 lifts were open and only 2 runs open.
(edited and updated 9/07/2024)

column8: Great place, went for the first time instead of going to the bigger snowfields which we normally would do. Staff are extremely friendly and the whole place has a great family feel to it. We only went up for the day just to toboggan as it was our little kids first time at the snow. Great tobogganing area but the magic carpet wasn’t working and so we needed to walk up the mountain ourselves which was hard for the small kids, so they were pretty buggered after a few runs. Other than that, it’s a cool place and looks like a chilled place to ski/board.

column8:
The taboggan Hill was fab with the magic carpet to take you up! $25 per person per day, not too bad. The food on the other hand $8 for a small cup of chips plus $1 per sauce... Suggest you take a picnic.
A lot of the snow was pretty well compacted so not ideal for snowball fights or building a snowman. *Don't forget $29 per car for parking too.
Staff were very friendly, high5's on the magic carpet and music playing and lady in the front was lovely helping us when the car machine wouldn't print our cards for us.

column8:
Substandard experience. It's hardly operating. Most of the place is closed.

One hour queue for gear, then 90% of the runs were closed despite excellent snowfall. They had more runs groomed but wouldn't operate the associated lifts. We only skied for three hours before the main chair lift broke down, forcing everyone onto the only remaining lift (T-bar) only to have that close too. Without a lift to use, and with most of the place inaccessible, we had to go home early. The resort closes at 4.30 but they had all the lifts shut down at 3.30.

If Selwyn wants customers, it needs to do better. You can't book hundreds of skiers then funnel them into only one ski run and one lift. 90% of the runs are closed. We tried to support their return to operation but it seems all the money has gone into the building and the lifts are broken. It's pretty sad.

Let us know when you're actually back up and running.

column8: It took us 90 minutes to collect our passes after pre-booking them online. The machines were broken and there were no signs to indicate where passes should be collected. The men's toilet was completely out of service on a very busy day (weekend and school holidays with good snow conditions) which led to the women's toilets becoming totally filthy.

column8: Awful experience.  My voucher didnt work and there is no way to call! You have to email and it takes 5 days to respond.  I had to purchase a other ticket but was told by customer service that i did infact validate all 3! Not true. I validated 3 because i purchased another. Staff at the ski lift were rude and impatient with beginner's. Lady at rentals was so busy servings multiple customers taking 1.15 mins to hire 1 pair of boots!!

column8:
We are a large family with 4 kids and Selwyn was the perfect place for everyone to ski and have a wonderful time. Very easy for the kids to learn, be close and safe. The instructors were absolutely wonderful with our children and were able to pick up skiing straight away. Very good value for money. We can’t wait to return!

column8: I specifically went to Mt Selwyn to support them after their years of heartache. It was excellent for my child to learn to ski even on the bad days. I did feel a bit let down that when snow arrived they were not ready to go in opening new terrain or even had their lifts properly serviced to do so (kept breaking down), especially considering how inadequate the immediate slopes are for anyone but first timers. Excellent family resort though without huge ques... but I do hope they can do better in opening up terrain more promptly in the future (when able to do so).

column8:
It's really been a long time since I last visited this place. 2006. Looks completely different than the last time I can remember (since I was a kid). Sad to hear it had burnt down druing the bush fires, but glad they were able to build back up and continue running. There is a free lift at the bottom to go to the bigger slops, and a magic carpet for the littler slop. Very glad to have come back and re-vist.

column11: Love this place! Perfect spot to learn to ski or snowboard with the fantastic international instructors. We had Chrisy from Munich, Germany. She is a legend, so good with the kids. I'm heading back today, I have to retrieve my snowboard.

column8:
We had a lovely few days visiting Selwyn this year. Highlights were the prompt and friendly service, tobogganing area and magic carpet are fantastic, it’s got a relaxed and friendly vibe - you don’t feel rushed and crowded like at other ski resorts. Food prices were high, but it’s to be expected with the logistics of getting food up a mountain. We enjoyed the burgers. Plenty of areas to sit and enjoy your own food too.

My son enjoyed his ‘first timer’ snowboarding lesson. The only minor issue was that it didn’t start until 9:15am because the instructors were all talking/socialising and then we waited for someone who was running late. The lesson then finished 10 minutes early at 10:50am, so my son lost 25 minutes of his lesson.
